description.narrative:
International Finance Corporation (IFC) har önskat stöd från Sida med 192 miljoner SEK för genomförandet av det regionala programmet "Financial Inclusion and Jobs for Middle East and North Africa (MENA MSME 2.0)" under 2019-2023.
Programmet är en regional multigivarfond vars avsikt är att stödja mikro, små- och medelstora företag (MSME: s) med att förbättra tillgången till finansiering och finansiella tjänster, främja hållbar skapande av arbetstillfällen och uppmuntra den privata sektorns tillväxt i regionen. Detta är den andra fasen av faciliteten och programmets föreslagna varaktighet är 2019-2023. Insatsen ligger inom ramen för MENA-strategins ekonomiska sektor "förbättrade möjligheter för regional ekonomisk utveckling som en förutsättning för att fattiga människor ska kunna förbättra sina levnadsvillkor". Programmet genomförs av två av Världsbanksgruppens underorgan, IFC samt Världsbanken (IBRD eller International Bank for Reconstruction and Development är det egentliga namnet, men benämns internt och i programdokumentationen som Världsbanken). IFC har det huvudsakliga ansvaret.
Skapandet av anständiga arbetstillfällen är en av de mest kritiska utmaningarna i en MENA (Mellanöstern-Nordafrika) -region som har genomgått en blandning av positiv och negativ demokratisk transition, ekonomisk stagnation, politisk oro och konflikter i nästan ett decennium sedan starten av den arabiska våren 2011. Dessa faktorer i kombination med en hög befolkningstillväxt har gjort att IFC uppskattar att det i den större Arabregionen behöver upp till 300 miljoner nya jobb fram till 2050.
Programmets interventionslogik bygger på resultaten från en tidigare fas samt dialog med ett stort antal intressenter. MSME: s är centrala element i alla MENA-ekonomier och utgör ungefär 85-95% av all sysselsättning i formella företag i regionen, och ännu mer om informella företag inkluderas. För att förbättra ekonomierna och skapa arbetstillfällen behövs det ett gynnsamt företagsklimat där företagen har tillgång till finansiering och finansiella tjänster vilket idag saknas i stor utsträckning. Utmaningarna inkluderar svaga regelverk, dålig kapacitet och begränsad förståelse om frågorna bland MSME: er. Den andra fasen av MSME-faciliteten kommer att hantera en rad olika hinder för ekonomisk inkludering och tillgång till finansiering som identifierades i fas ett.
Programmet har en väl utvecklad förändringsteori med ett tillhörande resultatramverk. Huvudsakliga effektmål är inkluderande tillväxt, sysselsättningsskapande och minskad ojämlikhet. Aktiviteter för att uppnå dessa mål kommer ske inom tre tematiska områden och ett tvärområde:
1. Stärka lagstiftning och kapacitet hos lagstiftande offentliga aktörer 2. Utveckla och stärka den finansiella infrastrukturen inklusive tekniska lösningar 3. Stöd till finansiella institutioner med fokus på kvinnor 4. Regional koordination, kunskapsdelning och metodutveckling
Den totala budgeten för programmet är drygt 48 miljoner dollar och programmet kommer genomföras i Marocko, Algeriet, Tunisien, Egypten, Jordanien, Libanon, Palestina och Irak. Stöden kommer huvudsakligen att ske genom rådgivningsaktiviteter från IFC och Världsbanken och någon vidareförmedling av medel till andra aktörer planeras inte. Förutom Sveriges stöd på 192 miljoner SEK finansieras programmet av Storbritannien och Schweiz. Ett begränsat underskott på 3 MUSD förväntas täckas av andra givare, alt av Världsbanksgruppen själva inom kort. Programmet är öppet för att genomföra avgiftsbelagda insatser som ligger inom dess intresse, men inte direkt inom ramen för resultatramverket. IFC har beräknat att dessa avgifter kan motsvara upp till en fjärdedel av givarnas bidrag.

Summary in English:
The International Finance Corporation has requested funding from Sweden for the implementation of the regional program "Financial Inclusion and Jobs for Middle East and North Africa (MENA MSME 2.0)". The total budget for the program is just over 48 million USD, and IFC has requested 192 million SEK from Sweden for the period 2019-2023. The program will be implemented in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine and Iraq.
The program is a multi-donor regional fund to support micro-small and medium sized companies (MSMEs) in getting improved access to finance and financial services, promote sustainable job creation, and encourage private sector growth in the region. This is the second phase of the facility and the program's proposed duration is 2019-2023. The intervention is within the framework of the economic sector of the Swedish MENA strategy, "improved opportunities for regional economic development as a prerequisite for poor people to be able to improve their living conditions". The program is implemented by two of the World Bank Groups organization, namely the IFC and the World Bank, where IFC will have the main responsibility.
Creating decent jobs is one of the most critical challenges in a MENA (Middle East-North Africa) region that has undergone a mix of positive and negative democratic transition, economic stagnation, political turmoil and conflicts for almost a decade since the start of the Arab Spring 2011. These factors combined with high population growth have meant that the IFC estimates that the greater Arabregion needs up to 300 million new jobs by 2050.
The program's intervention logic is based on the results of the first phase and dialogue with a large number of stakeholders. MSMEs are central to all MENA economies and account for approximately 85-95% of all formal private sector employees in the region. In order to improve the economies and create jobs, a favorable business climate is needed where the companies have access to finance and financial services, which is today largely lacking. The challenges include poor regulations, poor capacity and limited understanding of the issues among MSMEs. The second phase of the MSME facility will address various barriers to financial inclusion and access to funding identified in Phase One.
The program has a well-developed theory of change with a linked results framework. The impact goals are inclusive growth, job creation and reduced inequality. Activities to achieve these goals will be carried out within three thematic areas and one cross-sector area.
1. Strengthen the regulatory framework and capacity of legislative and implementing public actors 2. Develop and strengthen the financial infrastructure, including technical solutions 3. Support to financial institutions, with a focus on women 4. Regional coordination, knowledge sharing and method development
The total budget for the program is just over $ 48 million and the program will be implemented in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine and Iraq. The activities will primarily be through advisory activities from the IFC and the World Bank. No direct transfer of funds to third-party stakeholders is envisaged. In addition to Sweden's support of SEK 192 million, the program is funded by the UK and Switzerland. A current limited deficit of 3 million USD is expected to be covered by other donors in the near future.

The IFC MSME-facility 2.0 has a theory of change that is based on the results and experiences of the first phase as well as extensive consultations with a wide range of stakeholders. The overall impact goals in the results chain are job creation, GDP growth and decreased income inequality. The specific underlying MSME-facility impact goals include increased expansion and investments for MSME:s, increased profitability and productivity, MSME:s that are creating cascading effects for other enterprises in the same value chain. Under this impact objectives there is an outcome objective financial inclusion that include: - reduction of cost for MSME finance - ability to use movable collateral to obtain loans - increased access to financial services for MSMEs - increased access to financial services for women and youth These outcome objectives will be achieved by a number of activities within various priority areas (in the programme documents referred to as "Pillars". These pillars relationship and relevance for the intended impact on access to finance for MSMEs has also been assessed through evidence mappings conducted by the WBG MoE team. These pillars are: Regulatory Framework: - improvements in ease of doing business - MSME finance support regulations operationalized and in place Financial Infrastructure: - financial institutions consulting credit bureaus for credit worthiness - movable assets used as lending collateral - mediation procedures routinely used Financial Institutions: - increase in lending to MSMEs - increase offer of financial products to women, youth, MSMEs - increase lending to women-owned MSMEs - increased access to digital financing solutions

participating-org.narrative: IFC/International Finance Corporation/The World Bank Group
IFC/International Finance Corporation/The World Bank Group

tag.narrative: 8.10 - Strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
8.10 - Stärka de inhemska finansinstitutens kapacitet att främja och utöka tillgången till bank- och försäkringstjänster samt finansiella tjänster för alla.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

9.3 - Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets.

9.3 - Öka tillgången för småskaliga industriföretag och andra företag, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, till finansiella tjänster, inklusive överkomliga krediter, samt deras integrering i värdekedjor och marknader.

description.narrative:
Main expected results achieved (outputs) during 2021 at the pillar and country levels are described below.
Pillar I - Regulatory Framework:
Algeria: IFC/IBRD is working with the Bank of Algeria (BA) on developing the digital finance regulatory framework. IFC shared with Bank of Algeria two preliminary diagnostics: i) a review of the legal framework for payment systems; and ii) a comprehensive road map for a modernization strategy for the National Payment System in Algeria.
Morocco: an agri-finance project to review the agri-finance regulatory framework in Morocco is well underway. Interviews have been held with stakeholders for the regulatory framework review and the supply side review. Similarly, the demand side study and the review is well underway. A virtual event was held to disseminate the Focus Group Report for the Greenback Initiative. IFC is developing an action plan building on the findings of the report.
Tunisia: work continues on the improvement of the tax framework for NPL write-offs and the analysis of the legal framework for NPL resolution. Other activities have been fine-tuned following an initial discussion with the Ministry of Finance.
Egypt: IFC/IBRD the team received formal approval from the Ministry of International Cooperation. IBRD started work with the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) for the development of a national financial education strategy and strengthening the competition/consumer protection law for the banking sector. Also, IBRD started work with the Financial Regulatory Authority (FRA) to develop the secondary regulations of the draft fintech law.
Lebanon: IFC/IBRD has delivered to Bank of Lebanon a legislative guidance for e-signature regulations to implement the chapter on electronic banking and financial services regarding Law No. 81, the E-transaction law.
Pillar II - Financial Infrastructure:
Morocco: IFC continues to work with the central bank on credit reporting. An MOU was signed (July 12, 2021) as preparation by the IFC team of a detailed road map for the project, which was presented to Bank of Morocco (BAM) to agree on project time line and next steps. Furthermore, IFC is in discussions with BAM and the Director of the new Department of Statistics and Data Governance for the revamp of the public credit registry. After a diagnostic, IFC has signed at the end of June an agreement with BAM to assist them to develop a national Supply Chain Finance SCF strategy; Activities should start by early October. Last, an MOU has been signed with ACAPS, the regulator of the insurance industry, to help them to digitalise sector wide to facilitate access to digitized insurance.
Tunisia: A gap analysis was completed, and 26 recommendations to improve the credit registry were put forward. Also, IFC organized jointly with CRIF a workshop to support the Tunisian credit bureau. The workshop helped to raise the awareness of the credit bureau in Tunisia. The Tunisia Agri-insurance project was approved internally by IFC and tunisian stakeholders. IFC has been identifying potential insurance and distribution partners for the deployment of agricultural index insurance in Tunisia, support the assessment of potential demand for insurance by smallholder farmers, and assess the enabling environment.
Egypt: discussions are still ongoing with CBE regarding signing a legal agreement for the MSME 2.0. program activities. The agreement will likely be signed after the market assessment and the legal and regulatory assessment are finished by the end of 2021. IFC has been working on enhancing the enacted Secured Transactions Law. A revised draft of the law in English was finalized and its Arabic version completed and submitted to the client. In Egypt, IFC organized a training webinar for the legal community on Secured Transactions Law Reform in Egypt. The workshop aimed at discussing and raising awareness on the international standards and best practices of Secured Transactions and Asset Based Lending, various aspects of the Secured Transactions legal framework in Egypt and financing products that a modern Secured Transaction Law can facilitate for the benefit of MSMEs. Last, IFC conducted a virtual CCR Gap Analysis mission for the CBE , to run a diagnostic of the CBEs PCR, identify the gaps, and compare it with the existing international best practice.
Lebanon: the Lebanon Supply Chain Finance (SCF) project was approved and procurement has started for the legal and market assessments. Also, Lebanon Inclusive Insurance project was approved, and IFC is undertaking an insurance supply analysis and a MSMEs demand analysis. An intermediary report identifying priority economic sectors, where MSMEs play the most significant role, and estimated proportion/number of MSMEs in each, was completed.
Palestine: the Palestine Monetary Authority (PMA) and Palestine Capital Market Authority (PCMA) agreed to the scope of work on asset-based lending and credit information systems to boost levels of inclusion and enhance access to finance.
Iraq: the Central Bank of Iraq (CBI) agreed to IFCs proposal for technical assistance to enhance the credit reporting framework.
Pillar III - Financial Institutions:
Morocco: IFC conducted an assessment of the digital financial services (DFS) market. Final deliverables are expected in Q4 2021. Also, IFC is conducting a market assessment to gauge agri-finance demand. The study is underway and final deliverables are expected in Q4 2021. Both assessments should lay the ground for the identification of demand-driven financial products/services for MSMEs and for the selection of financial institutions to cooperated with in the supply side.
Tunisia: IFC has been conducting a large and comprehensive study of the Tunisian financial sector. The market assessment covers all aspects from MSME finance, digital financial services, agrifinance, as well as non-financial services across various target segments of interest. Again, the study should lay the ground for the identification of demand-driven financial products/services for MSMEs and for the selection of financial institutions to cooperated with in the supply side.
Egypt: IFC continues to work with Tanmeyah Micro Enterprise Services on diversifying Tanmeyahs product offering and strengthening its resilience by improving its risk management practices (i.e. stress-testing, etc.). IFC is presently working on the MSME product development component.
The program began at the same time as the pandemic ensued (early 2020). The inception phase of the program faced several delays not only of an operational nature. For example, pillar 1 "regulatory framework" projects lacked political commitment and governmental approval to initiate timely. It may be too early to harvest results (outcomes) in terms of jobs, sustainable economic growth, and reduction of inequality. However, operations are making a difference in improving public and financial sector counterparts' capacity to develop and deploy products and services for the target group (financial inclusion of MSMEs).
Operations have led to the identification of a common theme of projects at the pillar levels at the end of 2021. Work on improving regulatory framework (pillar 1) has been focusing on E-transaction, fintech, and digital finance law to enable financial access that facilitates trade. Another common project has been the treatment of non-performing loans write-offs, a common challenge in MENA. A common theme for upgrading financial infrastructure (pillar 2) has been developing credit registries, information systems, bureaus, and reporting projects. Then, inclusive insurance and supply chain finance for SMEs.
Advisory projects to specific financial institutions (pillar 3) have been diverse to foster digital financial services as means for financial inclusion. Still, analysis and studies continue to identify demand-driven financial products and services for MSMEs region-wide. Besides, risk management training to FI for stress testing has been delivered also as a preparatory step.
IFC has had difficulties reporting on results, focusing rather on providing an audit of activities at the country level. This concern has been raised to them during 2021. Future reports shall provide analysis, follow-up, and lessons learned from a regional perspective. IFC tends to focus focuses on their clients (governments and large financial institutions) rather than the ultimate target group (MSMEs) when informing on program progress and results. RBM and adaptive management support have been procured to resolve that situation going forward.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
